sum, esse, fuī, futūrus – to be
dīvidō, dīvidere, dīvīsī, dīvīsus – to divide, separate
incolō, incolere, incoluī – to inhabit, dwell
alius, alia, aliud (archaic: alis, alid) – other, another
ipse, ipsa, ipsum – himself, herself, itself (intensive)
Celtae –ārum m. – a great race in Gaul and Britain
appellō, appellāre, appellāvī, appellātus – to call
suī, sibi, sē, sē – himself, herself, itself (reflexive)
differō, differre, distulī, dīlātus – to scatter; divulge; differ
Garumna –ae f. – a river of southwest Gaul
Matrona –ae m. – the Matrona, a river of Gaul
cultus, cultūs m. – cultivation, civilization, dress, mode of life
absum, abesse, āfuī, āfutūrus – to be away, be absent
is, ea, id – he, she, it; that
commeō, commeāre – to go to and fro
ef–fēminō, –āre – to make feminine, represent as feminine
pertineō, pertinēre, pertinuī, pertentus – to reach
gerō, gerere, gessī, gestus – to bear, manage
causa, causae f. – cause, reason, lawsuit
Helvētius (Helvēticus) –a –um – of or from the Helvetii (tribe), Helvetian
contendō, contendere, contendī, contentus – to strain, exert
prohibeō, prohibēre, prohibuī, prohibitus – to prevent
obtineō, obtinēre, obtinuī, obtentus – to possess
dīcō, dīcere, dīxī, dictus – to say, speak
capiō, capere, cēpī, captus – to seize
contineō, continēre, continuī, contentus – to contain, restrain
attingō, attingere, attigī, attāctus – to touch
Sēquanus –a –um – of or belonging to the Sequani, a tribe that lived along the Sequana river
vergō, –ere – to incline; go down; verge on
orior, orīrī, ortus sum – to rise, be born
īnferus –a –um – low, vile; inhabitant of the underworld
spectō, spectāre, spectāvī, spectātus – to look at
occāsus, –ūs m. – going down; setting; the west
